Your Absorbing Discrete Diffusion Secretly Models the Conditional Distributions of Clean Data

Jingyang Ou1 â€ƒShen Nie1 â€ƒKaiwen Xue1 â€ƒFengqi Zhu1
Jiacheng Sun2 â€ƒZhenguo Li2 â€ƒChongxuan Li 1
1Gaoling School of Artificial Intelligence, Renmin University of China
2 Huawei Noahâ€™s Ark Lab
{oujingyang, nieshen,kaiwenxue,chongxuanli}@ruc.edu.cn;
fengqizhu@whu.edu.cn;{sunjiacheng1,li.zhenguo}@huawei.com Corresponding Author.
Abstract

Discrete diffusion models with absorbing processes have shown promise in language modeling. The key quantities to be estimated are the ratios between the marginal probabilities of two transitive states at all timesteps, called the concrete score. In this paper, we reveal that the concrete score in absorbing diffusion can be expressed as conditional probabilities of clean data, multiplied by a time-dependent scalar in an analytic form. Motivated by this finding, we propose reparameterized absorbing discrete diffusion (RADD), a dedicated diffusion model without time-condition that characterizes the time-independent conditional probabilities. Besides its simplicity, RADD can reduce the number of function evaluations (NFEs) by caching the output of the time-independent network when the noisy sample remains unchanged in a sampling interval. Empirically, RADD is up to 3.5 times faster while achieving similar performance with the strongest baseline. Built upon the new perspective of conditional distributions, we further unify absorbing discrete diffusion and any-order autoregressive models (AO-ARMs), showing that the upper bound on the negative log-likelihood for the diffusion model can be interpreted as an expected negative log-likelihood for AO-ARMs. Further, our RADD models achieve SOTA performance among diffusion models on 5 zero-shot language modeling benchmarks (measured by perplexity) at the GPT-2 scale. Our code is available at https://github.com/ML-GSAI/RADD.

1 Introduction

Auto-regressive modelsÂ [1, 2, 3] have dominated the area of language modeling for many years. In particular, such models significantly benefit from large-scale transformersÂ [4] and training data and have achieved remarkable progressÂ [5, 6, 7, 8]. From a probabilistic perspective, the sequential sampling process of auto-regressive models is inefficient and limits the reasoning ability in nonsequential ordersÂ [9, 10]. Intrinsically, this is because such models characterize the joint distribution by the chain rule of probability, motivating research on developing other types of generative models for text.

Diffusion modelsÂ [11, 12, 13] generate data in a coarse-to-fine manner efficientlyÂ [14, 15, 16, 17, 18] and all dimensions simultaneously, providing an appealing alternative to auto-regressive models. Among other effortsÂ [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 20, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29] (see SectionÂ 5 for a comprehensive discussion), score entropy discrete diffusion (SEDD)Â [29] has shown promise in text generation. In particular, SEDD has achieved comparable results to auto-regressive models on 5 zero-shot language modeling benchmarks at the GPT-2 scale. Meanwhile, SEDD can reduce the number of function evaluations (NFEs) in sampling and fulfill text conditioned on prompts at different positions.

Technically, SEDD employs a discrete-state (absorbing) Markov process that adds noises to data by randomly replacing a token with a mask token [M]delimited-[]M[\textbf{M}][ M ] and then learns a reverse process to denoise from an entirely masked sentence. The key quantities to be estimated in SEDD are the ratios between the marginal probabilities of two transitive states at all timesteps, called the concrete score. SEDD also proposes a â€œscaling trickâ€ (see details in SectionÂ 3) that scales the output of the score estimation by a factor. The trick has been proven very effective in practice yet not fully understood in theoryÂ [29].

One of our main contributions is to reveal that the concrete score in absorbing diffusion can be expressed as conditional probabilities of clean data, multiplied by a time-dependent scalar in an analytic form (see TheoremÂ 1). Our finding theoretically explains the benefits of the scaling trick as a reparameterization for better optimization. Motivated by the finding, we propose reparameterized absorbing discrete diffusion (RADD), a dedicated diffusion model that characterizes the time-independent conditional probabilities by removing the time conditions from the score estimation. Besides its simplicity, RADD can significantly reduce the NFEs by caching the output of the time-independent network when the noisy sample remains unchanged during a sampling interval (see Fig.Â 2).

Built upon the new understanding of the concrete score, we further unify absorbing discrete diffusion and any-order autoregressive models (AO-ARMs)Â [30, 31, 32], demonstrating that their training objectives are equivalent (see TheoremÂ 2). To establish the theory, we first rewrite the original training objective for absorbing discrete diffusion into a simpler form (named tğ‘¡titalic_t-denoising cross-entropy, tğ‘¡titalic_t-DCE). Then, we apply a change of variable from the time tğ‘¡titalic_t to the probability that a single-dimensional token is masked at time tğ‘¡titalic_t in the forward process. By integrating the probability variable analytically, we show its equivalence to the training objectives for AO-ARMs. These theoretical findings offer a fresh perspective that the upper bound on the negative log-likelihood of an absorbing discrete diffusion can be interpreted as the expected negative log-likelihood for corresponding AO-ARMs. Furthermore, they provide alternative objective functions for training and likelihood evaluation.

Empirically, RADD is up to 3.5 times faster in sampling while consistently achieving similar performance to the strongest baseline, i.e., SEDDÂ [29]. Moreover, we train our RADD models on different objective functions, achieving state-of-the-art performance among diffusion models on five zero-shot language modeling benchmarks (measured by perplexity) at the GPT-2 scale. This empirical evidence validates our theoretical findings.

In summary, this paper has several contributions:

  • â€¢

    Deeper understanding of discrete diffusion: Both the factorization form of the concrete score and unified training objective for absorbing discrete diffusion and AO-ARMs reveal important yet overlooked theoretical properties of absorbing discrete diffusion, which explain the mysterious scaling trick, provide practice guidance, and may inspire future work.

  • â€¢

    Simpler parameterization: By removing the time conditions, we reparameterize the model to focus on a time-independent conditional probability, simplifying the existing model.

  • â€¢

    Efficient sampling: Leveraging the reparameterized form, RADD with a caching strategy achieves consistently faster sampling.

  • â€¢

    Enhanced zero-shot language modeling performance: Our architectural simplifications and optimized training loss lead to superior results. On five zero-shot language modeling benchmarks, RADD achieves state-of-the-art performance among discrete diffusion models (measured by perplexity) at the GPT-2 scale.

2 Background

In this section, we introduce notations and preliminaries on continuous-time discrete diffusion models in SectionÂ 2.1 and any-order autoregressive models in SectionÂ 2.2.

Notation

We begin by establishing the notations used throughout the paper. Let lower, boldface lower and upper case letters represent scalers (e.g., ağ‘aitalic_a), vectors (e.g., ğ’‚ğ’‚{\bm{a}}bold_italic_a), and matrices (e.g., ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}}bold_italic_A), respectively. For a vector ğ’‚ğ’‚{\bm{a}}bold_italic_a, aisuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–a^{i}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes its iğ‘–iitalic_i-th element. For a matrix ğ‘¨ğ‘¨{\bm{A}}bold_italic_A, ğ‘¨â¢(i,j)ğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘—{\bm{A}}(i,j)bold_italic_A ( italic_i , italic_j ) denotes (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j)( italic_i , italic_j )-th element. For a vector function ğ’‡ğ’‡{\bm{f}}bold_italic_f, ğ’‡â¢(ğ’™)iğ’‡subscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{f}}({\bm{x}})_{i}bold_italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th element of ğ’‡â¢(ğ’™)ğ’‡ğ’™{\bm{f}}({\bm{x}})bold_italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Constants and random variables are not distinguished in the notation if there is no confusion. We represent the distributions of the forward and reverse processes by pğ‘pitalic_p and qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively. The transition probability from time sğ‘ sitalic_s to time tğ‘¡titalic_t is denoted by pt|s(â‹…|â‹…)p_{t|s}(\cdot|\cdot)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… | â‹… ), and the probability at time tğ‘¡titalic_t is denoted by ptâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡â‹…p_{t}(\cdot)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ). For complete notations and definitions, see AppendixÂ A.

The following Kolmogorovâ€™s forward equation holdsÂ [26, 33]:

ddâ¢tâ¢ğ‘·t|s=ğ‘·t|sâ¢ğ‘¸t.ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘·conditionalğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘·conditionalğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡\frac{d}{dt}{\bm{P}}_{t|s}={\bm{P}}_{t|s}{\bm{Q}}_{t}.divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG bold_italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . In practiceÂ [26, 29], ğ‘¸tsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡{\bm{Q}}_{t}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is parameterized as Ïƒâ¢(t)â¢ğ‘¸ğœğ‘¡ğ‘¸\sigma(t){\bm{Q}}italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) bold_italic_Q, where Ïƒâ¢(t)ğœğ‘¡\sigma(t)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) is a scalar function representing the noise schedule and ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q is a constant matrix. In this case, the solution to Eq.Â 2.3 can be solved analytically as ğ‘·t|s=expâ¡((ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)âˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s))â¢ğ‘¸)subscriptğ‘·conditionalğ‘¡ğ‘ Â¯ğœğ‘¡Â¯ğœğ‘ ğ‘¸{\bm{P}}_{t|s}=\exp\left((\bar{\sigma}(t)-\bar{\sigma}(s)){\bm{Q}}\right)bold_italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_exp ( ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) ) bold_italic_Q ), where ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)=âˆ«0tÏƒâ¢(s)â¢ğ‘‘sÂ¯ğœğ‘¡superscriptsubscript0ğ‘¡ğœğ‘ differential-dğ‘ \bar{\sigma}(t)=\int_{0}^{t}\sigma(s)dsoverÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) = âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ ( italic_s ) italic_d italic_s and exp\exproman_exp is the matrix exponential. Therefore, we can directly sample xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from xssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ x_{s}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in one step for any t>sğ‘¡ğ‘ t>sitalic_t > italic_s.

Further, ğ‘¸ğ‘¸{\bm{Q}}bold_italic_Q is often designed to diffuse towards a uniform distribution or an absorbing state [M]delimited-[]M[\textbf{M}][ M ]. Recent workÂ [20, 26] suggests that the absorbing matrix achieves better empirical performance. Besides, as detailed in SectionÂ 3, the specific structure of the absorbing matrix can be leveraged to improve performance and accelerate sampling. Therefore, we focus on the absorbing matrix as follows:

ğ‘¸absorb=[âˆ’10â‹¯010âˆ’1â‹¯01â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®â‹®00â‹¯âˆ’1100â‹¯00].superscriptğ‘¸absorbdelimited-[]10â‹¯0101â‹¯01â‹®â‹®â‹±â‹®â‹®00â‹¯1100â‹¯00\displaystyle{\bm{Q}}^{\text{absorb}}=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccccc}-1&0&\cdots&% 0&1\\ 0&-1&\cdots&0&1\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots&\vdots\\ 0&0&\cdots&-1&1\\ 0&0&\cdots&0&0\end{array}\right].bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT absorb end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL â‹¯ end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL â‹¯ end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL start_CELL â‹® end_CELL start_CELL â‹± end_CELL start_CELL â‹® end_CELL start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL â‹¯ end_CELL start_CELL - 1 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL â‹¯ end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY ] . (2.9)

The time reversal of the forward process is characterized by a reverse transition rate matrix ğ‘¸~tsubscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ [34, 35], whose element from state xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to state x^tsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\hat{x}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by

ğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,x^t)={ptâ¢(x^t)ptâ¢(xt)â¢ğ‘¸tâ¢(x^t,xt),xt^â‰ xt,âˆ’âˆ‘kâ‰ xtğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,k),x^t=xt.subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡casessubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡^subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},\hat{x}_{t})=\begin{cases}\frac{p_{t}(\hat{x}_{t})}% {p_{t}(x_{t})}{\bm{Q}}_{t}(\hat{x}_{t},x_{t}),&\hat{x_{t}}\neq x_{t},\\ -\sum_{k\neq x_{t}}\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},k),&\hat{x}_{t}=x_{t}.\end{cases}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL over^ start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k ) , end_CELL start_CELL over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (2.10)

Simulating the reverse process requires learning the reverse transition rate ğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,x^t)subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},\hat{x}_{t})over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). As ğ‘¸tâ¢(x^t,xt)subscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡{\bm{Q}}_{t}(\hat{x}_{t},x_{t})bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is known, it is sufficient to estimate the concrete score ptâ¢(x^t)ptâ¢(xt)subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\frac{p_{t}(\hat{x}_{t})}{p_{t}(x_{t})}divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG by a score network sÎ¸â¢(xt,t)â‰ˆ[ptâ¢(x^t)ptâ¢(xt)]x^tâˆˆğ’³subscriptğ‘ ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ’³s_{\theta}(x_{t},t)\approx[\frac{p_{t}(\hat{x}_{t})}{p_{t}(x_{t})}]_{\hat{x}_{% t}\in\mathcal{X}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) â‰ˆ [ divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ [28]. Denoising score entropy (DSE)Â [29] is an effective objective to train the score network

where Kâ¢(a):=aâ¢logâ¡aâˆ’aassignğ¾ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘K(a):=a\log a-aitalic_K ( italic_a ) := italic_a roman_log italic_a - italic_a. In particular, the DSE loss in Eq.Â 2.11 is an upper bound of the negative log-likelihood with an unknown gap. Nevertheless, existing workÂ [29] still employs it for training and likelihood evaluation.

After training, sampling can be understood as discretizing the following reverse process

ddâ¢sâ¢ğ‘·s|t=ğ‘·s|tâ¢ğ‘¸~s,ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘·conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘·conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘ \frac{d}{ds}{\bm{P}}_{s|t}={\bm{P}}_{s|t}\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{s},divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_s end_ARG bold_italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (2.12)

where dâ¢sğ‘‘ğ‘ dsitalic_d italic_s is an infinitesimal negative timestep and the concrete score is replaced by the score network. Existing samplers include the Euler method and Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ -leaping, as detailed in AppendixÂ D.

Multi-dimension

In a state space of length dğ‘‘ditalic_d like ğ’³d={1,â€¦,n}dsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘‘superscript1â€¦ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathcal{X}^{d}=\{1,\ldots,n\}^{d}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { 1 , â€¦ , italic_n } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we denote the sample as a sequence of one-dimensional data, i.e.,ğ’™=x1â¢â€¦â¢xdğ’™superscriptğ‘¥1â€¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘{\bm{x}}=x^{1}\ldots x^{d}bold_italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The transition matrix ğ‘¸tâˆˆâ„ndÃ—ndsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡superscriptâ„superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{Q}}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{d}\times n^{d}}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has an exponential number of possible states, making it expensive to reverse. To alleviate this issue, existing workÂ [26, 29] assumes independence between dimensions and each dimension is a one-dimensional diffusion process with the same transition rate matrix ğ‘¸ttokâˆˆâ„nÃ—nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¸tokğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›{\bm{Q}}^{\text{tok}}_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tok end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Under the independent assumption, ğ‘¸tsubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡{\bm{Q}}_{t}bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT assigns zero valuesÂ [26, 29] for all sequences with a Hamming distance larger than 1. Therefore, it is sufficient to model the concrete score between sequences that differ by a Hamming distance of 1, such as ğ’™^t=xt1â¢â€¦â¢x^tiâ¢â€¦â¢xtdsubscript^ğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â€¦superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{t}=x_{t}^{1}\ldots\widehat{x}_{t}^{i}\ldots x_{t}^{d}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given ğ’™t=xt1â¢â‹¯â¢xtdsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘{\bm{x}}_{t}=x_{t}^{1}\cdots x_{t}^{d}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Existing samplers assume that each dimension is independent within a small interval Î”â¢tÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta troman_Î” italic_t and update each dimension in parallel for efficiencyÂ [29, 26].

2.2 Any-order autoregressive models

Any-order autoregressive models (AO-ARMs)Â [30, 31, 32] model the joint distribution autoregressively for all possible orders Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ of the dğ‘‘ditalic_d variables. Formally, they factorize the joint distribution as âˆk=1dpâ¢(xÏ€â¢(k)|xÏ€(<k))superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptğ‘¥ğœ‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥annotatedğœ‹absentğ‘˜\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{\pi(k)}|x^{\pi(<k)})âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( < italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). To learn such a distribution, an AO-ARM utilizes a weight-sharing neural network to model all univariate conditionals and employs mask tokens to represent absent variables. During training, the expected negative log-likelihood over the uniform distribution of all orders UÏ€subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‹U_{\pi}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is minimized:

â„’Aâ¢Oâ¢(ğ’™0)subscriptâ„’ğ´ğ‘‚subscriptğ’™0\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{AO}({\bm{x}}_{0})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =ğ”¼Ï€âˆ¼UÏ€â¢âˆ‘l=1dlogâ¡qÎ¸â¢(x0Ï€â¢(l)|x0Ï€(<l);Ï€).absentsubscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‹subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğœ‹ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0annotatedğœ‹absentğ‘™ğœ‹\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\pi\sim U_{\pi}}\sum_{l=1}^{d}\log q_{\theta}(x_{0}^% {\pi(l)}|x_{0}^{\pi(<l)};\pi).= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ âˆ¼ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( < italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; italic_Ï€ ) . (2.16)

3 Reparameterized absorbing discrete diffusion

In SectionÂ 3.1, we reveal that the concrete score of absorbing discrete diffusion can be reparameterized as conditional distributions of clean data, which enables efficient sampling by caching the output of time-independent network (see SectionÂ 3.2). In SectionÂ 3.3, we unify the training objective of absorbing discrete diffusion and AO-ARMs.

3.1 Parameterizing the concrete score as conditional distributions of clean data

A key observation is that only the transition from the masked token to an unmasked token is valid in the reverse process of an absorbing discrete diffusion. In particular, according to the definition of the transition matrix of the absorbing process (seeÂ Eq.Â 2.9), we have ğ‘¸absorbâ¢(x^ti,xti)=0superscriptğ‘¸absorbsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–0{\bm{Q}}^{\text{absorb}}(\hat{x}_{t}^{i},x_{t}^{i})=0bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT absorb end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 for any unmasked xtiâ‰ [M]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mx_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}]italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] and x^tiâ‰ xtisuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{x}_{t}^{i}\neq x_{t}^{i}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, the corresponding element in the transition matrix of the reverse process ğ‘¸~tsubscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (seeÂ Eq.Â 2.10) equals zero. Namely,

Also, note that the concrete score always takes the value of one if x^ti=xtisuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–\hat{x}_{t}^{i}=x_{t}^{i}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, we only need to characterize the concrete score for xti=[M]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mx_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] and x^tiâ‰ [M]superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M\hat{x}_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}]over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ].

Interestingly, in this case, we discover that the concrete score has a simple analytic form w.r.t. to the conditional distributions of clean data, as summarized in the following TheoremÂ 1.

Theorem 1.

(Analytic concrete score in absorbing diffusion, proof in AppendixÂ B) For ğ±t=xt1â¢â€¦â¢xtiâ¢â€¦â¢xtdsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘{\bm{x}}_{t}=x_{t}^{1}\ldots x_{t}^{i}\ldots x_{t}^{d}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ±^t=xt1â¢â€¦â¢x^tiâ¢â€¦â¢xtdsubscript^ğ±ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{t}=x_{t}^{1}\ldots\widehat{x}^{i}_{t}\ldots x_{t}^{d}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, if xti=[M]superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mx_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] and x^tiâ‰ [M]superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M\hat{x}_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}]over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ], the concrete score at time tğ‘¡titalic_t can be expressed as a time-independent conditional distribution at time zero multiplied by an analytic time-dependent term:

ptâ¢(xt1â¢â€¦â¢x^tiâ¢â€¦â¢xtd)ptâ¢(xt1â¢â€¦â¢xtiâ¢â€¦â¢xtd)=eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢p0â¢(x^ti|ğ’™tUM),subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â€¦superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UM\frac{p_{t}\left(x_{t}^{1}\ldots\widehat{x}_{t}^{i}\ldots x_{t}^{d}\right)}{p_% {t}\left(x_{t}^{1}\ldots x_{t}^{i}\ldots x_{t}^{d}\right)}={\color[rgb]{1,.5,0% }\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}}{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}p_{0}(% \hat{x}_{t}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})},divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where ğ±tUMsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡UM{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the vector consists of all unmasked tokens of ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

One immediate implication of TheoremÂ 1 is to theoretically explain the benefit of the â€œscaling trickâ€ in existing workÂ [29] (see Appendix C.2 therein), which significantly improves the practical performance of discrete diffusion (see TableÂ 1) but has not been fully understood before. In particular, the scaling trick divides the output of the score network by a factor. Equivalently, it reparameterizes ğ’”Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)subscriptğ’”ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡{\bm{s}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) as follows:

ğ’”Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)=eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢ğ’”~Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t),subscriptğ’”ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscript~ğ’”ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡{\bm{s}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)={\color[rgb]{1,.5,0}\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t% )}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}}\tilde{{\bm{s}}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t),bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG over~ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) ,

where ğ’”~Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)subscript~ğ’”ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{s}}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)over~ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) is the output of the reparameterized score network and the scaling factor coincides with the time-dependent term in TheoremÂ 1. In the original parameterization, the score network sÎ¸subscriptğ‘ ğœƒs_{\theta}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must model the whole time-dependent concrete score. In contrast, with the scaling trick, the reparameterized score ğ’”~Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)subscript~ğ’”ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡\tilde{{\bm{s}}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)over~ start_ARG bold_italic_s end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) can focus on capturing the clean data distribution p0â¢(x^i|ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMp_{0}(\hat{x}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and simplifies learning, according to TheoremÂ 1.

Further, TheoremÂ 1 suggests that the reparameterized score is essentially a conditional probability on clean data, which is time-independent. Motivated by the insights, we propose reparameterized absorbing discrete diffusion (RADD), which employs a time-independent network ğ’„Î¸â¢(ğ’™t)subscriptğ’„ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{c}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) that defines a model distribution qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by corresponding conditional distributions to approximate data distribution p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT directly:

ğ’„Î¸â¢(ğ’™t)â¢[i,x^ti]=qÎ¸â¢(x^ti|ğ’™tUM)â‰ˆp0â¢(x^ti|ğ’™tUM).subscriptğ’„ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMsubscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UM{\bm{c}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})[i,\hat{x}_{t}^{i}]=q_{\theta}(\hat{x}_{t}^{i}|% {\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})\approx p_{0}(\hat{x}_{t}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm% {UM}}).bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) [ italic_i , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (3.2)

In practice, we make a minimal modification of the score network in SEDDÂ [29] for simplicity and fairness. Briefly, we remove the time condition from the input and take the softmax as the final nonlinearity. Further details can be found in SectionÂ G.1.

Moreover, RADD also enjoys a more efficient sampling process than SEDDÂ [29] based on its simplified parameterization, as presented below.

3.2 Efficient samplers to reduce NFEs by caching the output of RADD

In the reverse process of an absorbing discrete diffusion, once a token transitions from [M]delimited-[]M[\textbf{M}][ M ] to an unmasked token, it remains unchanged. Consequently, for a sequence consisting of dğ‘‘ditalic_d tokens, there will be at most dğ‘‘ditalic_d intervals during the sampling process where changes occur, regardless of the number of sampling steps Dğ·Ditalic_D. In the remaining steps, the sequence remains unchanged across all dğ‘‘ditalic_d dimensions. This property allows us to cache ğ’„Î¸â¢(xt)subscriptğ’„ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡{\bm{c}}_{\theta}(x_{t})bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to avoid the need to reevaluate the time-independent ğ’„Î¸subscriptğ’„ğœƒ{\bm{c}}_{\theta}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unchanged in the previous step (see AppendixÂ F for the pseudo-code). However, since SEDD is conditioned on time, it does not support this caching strategy for reducing NFEs.

The NFEs with the caching strategy is a random variable. To quantify it, we calculate the expected NFEs (E-NFEs) in analytic form, conditioned on the sampling method, time steps, and noise schedule. For instance, using the Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method with a log-linear noise scheduleÂ [29], the E-NFEs is given by (proof in SectionÂ D.5):

E-NFEsâ¢(n)=nâ¢(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1n)l),E-NFEsğ‘›ğ‘›1superscript11ğ‘›ğ‘™\text{E-NFEs}(n)=n(1-(1-\frac{1}{n})^{l}),E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = italic_n ( 1 - ( 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (3.3)

where nğ‘›nitalic_n represents the sampling steps and lğ‘™litalic_l represents the length to be generated.

In Fig.Â 2, we plot the curve of Eq.Â 3.3 in blue, which aligns well with our experiments (the red stars). This demonstrates that our method theoretically reduces E-NFEs significantly when the number of sampling steps is large, and this reduction is also confirmed experimentally in Fig.Â 2.

Furthermore, based on TheoremÂ 1, simplified forms of the reverse process for both Euler method and Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ -leaping method can be derived, which leads to corresponding analytic forms of E-NFEs given time steps and noise schedule. We also prove that these two sampling methods are equivalent under a log-linear noise schedule for absorbing discrete diffusion (see AppendixÂ D for more details).

3.3 Unifying absorbing discrete diffusion and any-order autoregressive models

Building upon TheoremÂ 1, we further prove the equivalence between absorbing discrete diffusion and any-order autoregressive modelsÂ [30, 31, 32], as presented in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

The absorbing discrete diffusion objective of Eq.Â 2.11 is equivalent to any-order autoregressive objective of Eq.Â 2.16 when the final total noise level ÏƒÂ¯â¢(T)â†’+âˆâ†’Â¯ğœğ‘‡\bar{\sigma}(T)\rightarrow+\inftyoverÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_T ) â†’ + âˆ.

The proof of TheoremÂ 2 consists of three key steps, which introduce three different yet equivalent loss functions. Below we briefly present the key ideas and defer the proof in AppendixÂ C.

In the first step, by removing the terms ğ’”Î¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)ğ’™^tsubscriptğ’”ğœƒsubscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡subscript^ğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{s}}_{\theta}\left({\bm{x}}_{t},t\right)_{\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{t}}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Kâ¢(ptâˆ£0â¢(ğ’™^tâˆ£ğ’™0)ptâˆ£0â¢(ğ’™tâˆ£ğ’™0))ğ¾subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘¡0conditionalsubscript^ğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™0subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘¡0conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™0K\left(\frac{p_{t\mid 0}\left({\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{t}}\mid{\bm{x}}_{0}\right)}{p_{% t\mid 0}\left({\bm{x}}_{t}\mid{\bm{x}}_{0}\right)}\right)italic_K ( divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t âˆ£ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) in Eq.Â 2.11, we can define a simpler loss â„’tâ¢-DCETsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘¡-DCEğ‘‡\mathcal{L}_{t\textrm{-DCE}}^{T}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT called tğ‘¡titalic_t-denoising cross-entropy loss (abbr. tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE), which is equivalent to DSE loss. In the multi-dimensional case, it has the form:

â„’tâ¢-DCETâ¢(ğ’™0)superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘¡-DCEğ‘‡subscriptğ’™0\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{t\textrm{-DCE}}^{T}({\bm{x}}_{0})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =âˆ«0Tğ”¼ğ’™tâˆ¼pt|0â¢(ğ’™t|ğ’™0)â¢[âˆ‘xti=[M]âˆ’Ïƒâ¢(t)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢logâ¡(eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢qÎ¸â¢(x0i|ğ’™tUM))]â¢ğ‘‘t.absentsuperscriptsubscript0ğ‘‡subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘¡0conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™0delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mğœğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMdifferential-dğ‘¡\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{T}\mathbb{E}_{{\bm{x}}_{t}\sim p_{t|0}({\bm{x}}_{t}|{% \bm{x}}_{0})}\left[\sum_{x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]}-\frac{\sigma(t)e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}\log\left(\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^% {-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}q_{\theta}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})\right)% \right]dt.= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t | 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ] italic_d italic_t . (3.4)

We emphasize that Eq.Â 3.4 holds in a nonparametric setting because RADD can be interpreted as a model distribution qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the conditional distribution of clean data, which approximates the true distribution p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as proven inÂ TheoremÂ 1.

In the second step, inspired by Â Kingma etÂ al. [36], we change the variable from tğ‘¡titalic_t to Î»â¢(t)=1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)ğœ†ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡\lambda(t)=1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}italic_Î» ( italic_t ) = 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which represents the probability of a token being masked in [0,t]0ğ‘¡[0,t][ 0 , italic_t ] during the forward process. Thus, â„’tâ¢-DCETâ¢(ğ’™0)subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ‘‡ğ‘¡-DCEsubscriptğ’™0\mathcal{L}^{T}_{t\textrm{-DCE}}({\bm{x}}_{0})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be rewritten as an integral of Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î», defined as Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»-denoising cross-entropy loss (abbr. Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE):

â„’Î»â¢-DCEâ¢(ğ’™0):=âˆ«011Î»â¢ğ”¼ğ’™Î»âˆ¼pÎ»â¢(ğ’™Î»|ğ’™0)â¢[âˆ‘xÎ»i=[M]âˆ’logâ¡qÎ¸â¢(ğ’™0i|ğ’™Î»UM)]â¢ğ‘‘Î»,assignsubscriptâ„’ğœ†-DCEsubscriptğ’™0superscriptsubscript011ğœ†subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ’™ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğœ†conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğœ†subscriptğ’™0delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœ†ğ‘–delimited-[]Msubscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğœ†UMdifferential-dğœ†\mathcal{L}_{\lambda\textrm{-DCE}}({\bm{x}}_{0}):=\int_{0}^{1}\frac{1}{\lambda% }\mathbb{E}_{{\bm{x}}_{\lambda}\sim p_{\lambda}({\bm{x}}_{\lambda}|{\bm{x}}_{0% })}\left[\sum_{x_{\lambda}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]}-\log q_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{0}^{i}|% {\bm{x}}_{\lambda}^{\textrm{UM}})\right]d\lambda,caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_log italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] italic_d italic_Î» , (3.5)

where pÎ»â¢(ğ’™Î»|ğ’™0)subscriptğ‘ğœ†conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğœ†subscriptğ’™0p_{\lambda}({\bm{x}}_{\lambda}|{\bm{x}}_{0})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the joint distribution induced by masking each dimension in ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0{\bm{x}}_{0}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT independently with a probability Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î».

Finally, we prove that Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE loss in Eq.Â 3.5 can be integrated analytically and rewritten as â„’Aâ¢Osubscriptâ„’ğ´ğ‘‚\mathcal{L}_{AO}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq.Â 2.16. We summarize our proof procedure by the equivalence between these losses:

â„’DSETâ¢(ğ’™0)â¢â‡”Appendixâ¢C.1â¢â„’tâ¢-DCETâ¢(ğ’™0)â¢â‡”Appendixâ¢C.2â¢â„’Î»â¢-DCEâ¢(ğ’™0)â¢â‡”Appendixâ¢C.3â¢â„’Aâ¢Oâ¢(ğ’™0).superscriptsubscriptâ„’DSEğ‘‡subscriptğ’™0AppendixC.1iffsuperscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘¡-DCEğ‘‡subscriptğ’™0AppendixC.2iffsubscriptâ„’ğœ†-DCEsubscriptğ’™0AppendixC.3iffsubscriptâ„’ğ´ğ‘‚subscriptğ’™0\mathcal{L}_{\textrm{DSE}}^{T}({\bm{x}}_{0})\overset{\textrm{Appendix}~{}\ref{% subsec:DSE/DCE}}{\iff}\mathcal{L}_{t\textrm{-DCE}}^{T}({\bm{x}}_{0})\overset{% \textrm{Appendix}~{}\ref{subsec:DCEloss_lambda}}{\iff}\mathcal{L}_{\lambda% \textrm{-DCE}}({\bm{x}}_{0})\overset{\textrm{Appendix}~{}\ref{subsec:DCEloss_k% }}{\iff}\mathcal{L}_{AO}({\bm{x}}_{0}).caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT DSE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_OVERACCENT Appendix end_OVERACCENT start_ARG â‡” end_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_OVERACCENT Appendix end_OVERACCENT start_ARG â‡” end_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_OVERACCENT Appendix end_OVERACCENT start_ARG â‡” end_ARG caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (3.6)

A direct benefit from TheoremÂ 2 is that we can use an absorbing discrete diffusion model to sample like AO-ARM and vice versa. For training and likelihood evaluation, the four losses in Eq.Â 3.6 can also be used (see AppendixÂ F for pseudo-code). To efficiently estimate the four losses using Monte Carlo methods, we can replace the sum or integral with an expectation. Take Eq.Â 3.5 for example, it can be rewritten as the following form of expectation on Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»:

â„’Î»â¢-DCEâ¢(ğ’™0)=ğ”¼Î»âˆ¼Uâ¢([0,1])â¢1Î»â¢ğ”¼ğ’™Î»âˆ¼pÎ»â¢(ğ’™Î»|ğ’™0)â¢[âˆ‘xÎ»i=[M]âˆ’logâ¡qÎ¸â¢(ğ’™0i|ğ’™Î»UM)].subscriptâ„’ğœ†-DCEsubscriptğ’™0subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ†ğ‘ˆ011ğœ†subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ’™ğœ†subscriptğ‘ğœ†conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğœ†subscriptğ’™0delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœ†ğ‘–delimited-[]Msubscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğœ†UM\mathcal{L}_{\lambda\textrm{-DCE}}({\bm{x}}_{0})=\mathbb{E}_{\lambda\sim U([0,% 1])}\frac{1}{\lambda}\mathbb{E}_{{\bm{x}}_{\lambda}\sim p_{\lambda}({\bm{x}}_{% \lambda}|{\bm{x}}_{0})}\left[\sum_{x_{\lambda}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]}-\log q_{% \theta}({\bm{x}}_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{\lambda}^{\textrm{UM}})\right].caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» âˆ¼ italic_U ( [ 0 , 1 ] ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_log italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] . (3.7)

Additionally, TheoremÂ 2 provides a new perspective on the DSE loss. While it has been traditionally viewed as an upper bound on the negative log-likelihood for the diffusion model, it can also be interpreted as an expected negative log-likelihood over factorial numbers of orderings for AO-ARM by Eq.Â 2.16. As discussed inÂ [30], for different orders Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€, qÎ¸â¢(x0;Ï€)subscriptğ‘ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥0ğœ‹q_{\theta}(x_{0};\pi)italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_Ï€ ) will be inconsistent in general. Despite this inconsistency, it can be viewed as an ensemble of multiple autoregressive models with different orders, potentially more robust than fixed-order models.

4 Experiments

We present the experimental setups in SectionÂ 4.1. We then evaluate the performance of accelerated generation in SectionÂ 4.2 and zero-shot perplexity on various language datasets in SectionÂ 4.3.

4.1 Settings

Below, we briefly present the experimental settings. For more details, please see AppendixÂ G.

Model.

We use RADD model ğ’„Î¸subscriptğ’„ğœƒ{\bm{c}}_{\theta}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reparameterzied as described in SectionÂ 3.1. Compared with SEDD small model, RADD model has 7M fewer parameters due to the removal of time-condition, which equates to an 8% decrease from the original 90M non-embedding parameters. We trained our RADD model ğ’„Î¸subscriptğ’„ğœƒ{\bm{c}}_{\theta}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using denoising score entropy, tğ‘¡titalic_t-denoising cross-entropy, Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»-denoising cross-entropy and any-order autoregressive loss, abbreviated as RADD-DSE, RADD-tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE, RADD-Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE and RADD-AO. For the SEDD small model, we employed their pre-trained model. In text generation tasks, we used RADD-tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE.

Data.

Following SEDD, we trained on the OpenWebTextÂ [37] dataset and tested on the LAMBADA, WikiText2, PTB, WikiText103, and One Billion Words datasetsÂ [38, 39, 40, 41]. For data splits and data processing, we adopted the same settings and techniques as SEDD, which involves packing sentences to generate uniform-length blocks as model input.

Training setup.

We used a log-linear noise schedule where the expectation of the number of changed tokens at time tğ‘¡titalic_t is linear with tğ‘¡titalic_t. For RADD-DSE, we use the same hyperparameter with SEDD for fair comparison. For other RADD models, we referenced the hyperparameter in [42].

Metric.

Following previous workÂ [29], we conduct experiments on unconditional generation and language modeling tasks. For generation, we use perplexity (PPL) on unconditional samples measured by an additional larger language model (i.e.,GPT-2 large) to evaluate sample quality. For language modeling tasks, we report the perplexity calculated on the dataset with different models.

4.2 Efficient sampling

We compare the sample quality measured by perplexity between SEDD and our RADD-tğ‘¡titalic_t-DCE model under a log-linear noise schedule. As shown in Fig.Â 2, RADD with the caching strategy is more efficient than SEDD, with efficiency gains increasing as the number of sample steps increases. This improvement is expected because the NFEs is limited by the generating sequence length. We further compare the running time as detailed in SectionÂ G.4.

As discussed in SectionÂ 3.3, we can also use RADD as an any-order autoregressive model to generate samples in different orders, leading to worse performance as a discrete diffusion, as detailed in SectionÂ G.4. We present more sampling details in SectionÂ G.3. and the generated samples in SectionÂ H.1.

4.3 Improved zero-shot perplexity on language modeling

Following SEDD, we present zero-shot perplexities on the LAMBADA, WikiText2, PTB, WikiText103, and 1 Billion Words datasetsÂ [43] in TableÂ 1111In the initial version of the RADD model, we mistakenly removed the time-dependent bias term in the layernorm layer without adding a bias term that is independent of time. In the latest implementation, we have fixed this bug. and compare the zero-shot perplexity of our model with other baseline modelsÂ [20, 44, 29]. This table reports results for RADD models trained for 400k iterations. Further, we provide the results of RADD models that are trained with 1000k iterations in TableÂ 2.

Firstly, we conduct an ablation study of the scaling trick in the middle of theÂ TableÂ 1. For the absorbing diffusion, the perplexity of the scaled version of SEDD outperforms its unscaled version, which matches our theoretical discovery in TheoremÂ 1.

Secondly, with the same DSE loss and hyperparameters, we observed that the RADD-DSE model without time-conditioning performs comparably to the SEDD-S model with time-conditioning. This validates our analysis in SectionÂ 3.1, indicating that time-conditioning is unnecessary for absorbing discrete diffusion models.

Thirdly, we report the results of RADD models trained on other equivalent losses in the last three rows of theÂ TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 2. Their perplexities are calculated based on their corresponding loss (e.g., RADD-Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE on â„’Î»â¢-DCE)\mathcal{L}_{\lambda\textrm{-DCE}})caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î» -DCE end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which is valid for likelihood estimation as discussed in SectionÂ 3.3. We observed that the RADD-tğ‘¡titalic_t-DCE and RADD-AO consistently outperform SEDD, while RADD-Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î»-DCE also outperforms SEDD on all tasks except LAMBADA. These results demonstrate the correctness of our conclusion in SectionÂ 3.3 while showing that the empirical contributions of [42] also apply to RADD for better performance.

5 Related work

Continouous-state diffusion models for text generation.

Several works have been proposed to apply continuous diffusion to textÂ [19, 21, 22, 23]. Li etÂ al. [19] use an embedding layer to map discrete tokens to a latent space and learn a continuous-state diffusion on it. Bit DiffusionÂ [22] learns a continuous diffusion model to generate binary bits of discrete tokens. However, transforming between these continuous representations and discrete tokens by thresholding may lose information. Bayesian Flow NetworkÂ [23] achieves competitive log-likelihood on character-level language modeling tasks and is proven equivalent to continuous stochastic differential equations trained by denoising score matchingÂ [24]. Such models underperform auto-regressive models on standard text generation tasks.

Discrete-state diffusion models for text generation.

Several discrete-state diffusion models have been proposedÂ [11, 45, 20]. D3PMÂ [20] proposed a diffusion framework based on any probability transition matrix and trained with a lower bound of log-likelihood. DiffusionBERTÂ [25] utilizes a pre-trained BERTÂ [46] as an initialization of diffusion. Furthermore,Â [26] generalizes the framework to continuous time by introducing a rate matrix. It is difficult to apply the score matching in such models because the gradient of the data distribution is undefined. Several works try to generalize the score matching on discrete dataÂ [29, 28, 26, 27].Â Meng etÂ al. [28] introduce the concrete score and the denoising concrete score matching loss. Furthermore, SEDD bridges the discrete state diffusion and the concrete score by introducing a denoising score entropy lossÂ [29]. By incorporating an absorbing process, SEDD achieves competitive performance with the auto-regressive models, especially, GPT-2.

Concurrent works

We mention that Shi etÂ al. [42] and Sahoo etÂ al. [47] independently conducted related studies on absorbing discrete diffusion and we provide a comprehensive discussion here.

Shi etÂ al. [42] derived a weighted integral of cross-entropy loss in their Eq.(5) similar to our tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE loss in Eq.Â 3.4. Besides, their Proposition 1, which connects the score parameterization and the mean parameterization222Our conclusions are based on score parameterization but can be extended to mean prediction parameterization (please see AppendixÂ E)., also resembles our TheoremÂ 1. In comparison, we simplified the conditional expectation term (related to tğ‘¡titalic_t) in Proposition 1Â [42] to a time-independent conditional probability at time zero. Motivated by the finding, we proposed a simpler parameterization that enables fast sampling. It is worth noting that the hyperparameters they selected significantly contribute to the modelâ€™s performance, which also applies to our RADD models (see SectionÂ G.2 for details). In addition, Shi etÂ al. [42] proposed a generalized masked diffusion model allowing state-dependent masking schedules.

Sahoo etÂ al. [47] derive the same cross-entropy losses with Shi etÂ al. [42]. Despite lacking a theoretical foundation, they conducted time-conditioning ablation which shows that time-conditioning has minimal impact on perplexity. They also proposed a caching strategy to accelerate sampling. While this coincides with our work in SectionÂ 3.2, we present a complete theoretical analysis of E-NFEs to quantify the acceleration efficiency.

Compared with the concurrent works, our research offers a complementary perspective on absorbing diffusion, reveals its time-independent property, proposes a theoretically sound cache strategy for fast sampling, derives two additional loss functions, and connects it to any-order autoregressive models.

6 Conclusion

We introduce RADD, a dedicated discrete diffusion model that characterizes the time-independent conditional probabilities, built upon a new factorization form of the concrete score. RADD is much more efficient by reducing the NFEs with a cache strategy while maintaining comparable performance to strong baselines. Additionally, we demonstrated the unification of training objectives for absorbing discrete diffusion and AO-ARMs. On five zero-shot language modeling benchmarks, our RADD models achieve state-of-the-art performance at the GPT-2 scale.

Limitaition.

Our model has been trained and evaluated primarily on the GPT-2 scale. For broader applicability, it is essential to explore the effects of scaling on the performanceÂ [48], which is left as future work. The success of diffusion transformers on imagesÂ [49, 50, 51] and videosÂ [52] suggests that diffusion models can be scaled up by incorporating transformers.

Another limitation is that our model can only generate full-length outputs, unlike auto-regressive models that can produce variable-length outputs. This restricts the flexibility of our model in certain applications. We leave the investigation on this issue as future work.

Social impact. For the current theoretical and experimental scope of this paper, we have not found any direct social impacts. However, considering future developments, the paper potentially contributes to the next-generation large language models. In this context, this work could significantly reduce the inference cost of language models but may also lead to hallucinations, amplify biases and discrimination in the data, and pose risks of misuse. As with other generative models, addressing these issues requires further advancements in the field.

Acknowledgments

We thank Aaron Lou for his prompt and detailed responses to our inquiries, which greatly assisted our research. We also thank Zebin You for his support in setting up the coding environment.
