Simplifying these equations, we can express ps|tâ¢(ğ’™s|ğ’™t)subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{s|t}({\bm{x}}_{s}|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as

ps|tâ¢(ğ’™s|ğ’™t)={[eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)]Î”â¢dâ¢[1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)]d1â¢p0â¢(ğ’™sUM)p0â¢(ğ’™tUM),ğ’™tâŠ†UMğ’™s,0,ğ’™tâŠˆUMğ’™s.subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡casessuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ Î”ğ‘‘superscriptdelimited-[]1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ 1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘0superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ UMsubscriptğ‘0superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMsubscriptUMsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘ 0subscriptnot-subset-of-or-equalsUMsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘ p_{s|t}({\bm{x}}_{s}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}\left[\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s% )}-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}}\right]^{\Delta d}\left[\frac{% 1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}\right]^{d_{1}}\frac{p_{0}({\bm% {x}}_{s}^{\textrm{UM}})}{p_{0}({\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})},&{\bm{x}}_{t}% \subseteq_{\text{UM}}{\bm{x}}_{s},\\ 0,&{\bm{x}}_{t}\not\subseteq_{\text{UM}}{\bm{x}}_{s}.\end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL [ divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - âˆ

It should be noted that when ğ’™tâŠ†UMğ’™ssubscriptUMsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘ {\bm{x}}_{t}\subseteq_{\text{UM}}{\bm{x}}_{s}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the ratio p0â¢(ğ’™sUM)p0â¢(ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ UMsubscriptğ‘0superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UM\frac{p_{0}({\bm{x}}_{s}^{\textrm{UM}})}{p_{0}({\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})}divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG can be reformulated as a d1subscriptğ‘‘1d_{1}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-dimensional conditional distribution p0â¢(ğ’™sUM|ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ UMsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMp_{0}({\bm{x}}_{s}^{\textrm{UM}}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with Nd1superscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘‘1N^{d_{1}}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT states. This is not accessible using our one-dimensional conditional distribution p0â¢(x^ti|ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMp_{0}(\hat{x}_{t}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in TheoremÂ 1 if d1>1subscriptğ‘‘11d_{1}>1italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 1. Therefore, for efficiency, existing samplers assume that each dimension is independent within a small interval and update each dimension in parallelÂ [29, 26].

D.2 Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method and its simplified form in RADD

Given the vector ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if we sample each xsisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–x_{s}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT independently, the factorization of marginal distribution ps|ttweediesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡tweediep_{s|t}^{\text{tweedie}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT results in the minimum KL divergence with true reverse ps|tâ¢(ğ’™s|ğ’™t)subscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡conditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{s|t}({\bm{x}}_{s}|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (proof in Â [29], Appendix A). This assumption formally defines ps|ttweediesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡tweediep_{s|t}^{\text{tweedie}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as follows:

ps|ttweedieâ¢(ğ’™s|ğ’™t)=âˆi=1dps|ttweedie,iâ¢(xsi|ğ’™t)=âˆi=1dps|tiâ¢(xsi|ğ’™t).superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡tweedieconditionalsubscriptğ’™ğ‘ subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡tweedieğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{s|t}^{\text{tweedie}}({\bm{x}}_{s}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\prod_{i=1}^{d}p_{s|t}^{% \text{tweedie},i}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\prod_{i=1}^{d}p_{s|t}^{i}(x_{s}^{i}% |{\bm{x}}_{t}).italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (D.6)

To sample from ps|ttweediesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡tweediep_{s|t}^{\text{tweedie}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we need to derive the analytic form of ps|tiâ¢(xsi|ğ’™t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{s|t}^{i}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). =eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢p0â¢(xs1|ğ’™td1+1:d).absentsuperscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ 1superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡:subscriptğ‘‘11ğ‘‘\displaystyle=\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t)}}{p_{0}(x_{s}^{1}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{d_{1}+1:d})}.= divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 : italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Here, we used the binomial expansion identity:

âˆ‘k=0d1âˆ’1Cd1âˆ’1kâ¢[eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)]k=[1+eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)]d1âˆ’1.superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0subscriptğ‘‘11superscriptsubscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘‘11ğ‘˜superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ ğ‘˜superscriptdelimited-[]1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ subscriptğ‘‘11\sum_{k=0}^{d_{1}-1}C_{d_{1}-1}^{k}\left[\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}}\right]^{k}=\left[1+\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}% (s)}-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}}\right]^{d_{1}-1}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ 1 + divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

(D.7)

In general, we have

ps|tiâ¢(xsi|ğ’™t)={eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢p0â¢(xsi|ğ’™tUM),xsiâ‰ [M],xti=[M],1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t),xsi=[M],xti=[M],Î´xsiâ¢xti,xtiâ‰ [M].superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡casessuperscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ 1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Msubscriptğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mp_{s|t}^{i}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}-e^% {-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{p_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{% \textrm{UM}})},&x_{s}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ \frac{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}},&x_{s}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],% x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ \delta_{x_{s}^{i}x_{t}^{i}},&x_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}].\end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - D.3 Euler method and its simplified form in RADD

According to theory of CTMCÂ [35, 26, 29], given a particular one-dimensional input xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the transition probabilities to xssubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ x_{s}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be approximately calculated using Eq.Â 2.1 and Eq.Â 2.12 as follows:

â‰ˆÎ´xtâ¢xs+ğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,xs)â¢(tâˆ’s),absentsubscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ \displaystyle\approx\delta_{x_{t}x_{s}}+\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},x_{s})(t-s),â‰ˆ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_t - italic_s ) , (D.10)

where

ğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,xs)subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ \displaystyle\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},x_{s})over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ={ğ‘¸tâ¢(xs,xt)â¢ptâ¢(xs)ptâ¢(xt),xtâ‰ xs,âˆ’âˆ‘kâ‰ xtğ‘¸~tâ¢(xt,k),xt=xs.absentcasessubscriptğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscript~ğ‘¸ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ \displaystyle=\begin{cases}{\bm{Q}}_{t}(x_{s},x_{t})\frac{p_{t}(x_{s})}{p_{t}(% x_{t})},&x_{t}\neq x_{s},\\ -\sum_{k\neq x_{t}}\tilde{{\bm{Q}}}_{t}(x_{t},k),&x_{t}=x_{s}.\end{cases}= { start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (D.11)

Therefore, we can define the Euler approximation of the transition probabilityÂ [26, 29]:

In the case of absorbing diffusion, similar to Tweedie-Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ leaping method in SectionÂ D.2, we can use TheoremÂ 1 and Eq.Â 2.9 to simplify Eq.Â D.12, which results in

ps|teuler,iâ¢(xsi|ğ’™t)={Ïƒâ¢(t)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢(tâˆ’s)â¢p0â¢(xsi|ğ’™tUM),ifÂ â¢xsiâ‰ [M],xti=[M]1âˆ’Ïƒâ¢(t)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢(tâˆ’s),ifÂ â¢xsi=[M],xti=[M]Î´xsiâ¢xti,xtiâ‰ [M].superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡eulerğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡casesğœğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘ subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMformulae-sequenceifÂ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M1ğœğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘ formulae-sequenceifÂ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Msubscriptğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mp_{s|t}^{\text{euler},i}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}\sigma(t)\frac{e% ^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s)p_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^% {\textrm{UM}}),&\text{if }x_{s}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]\\ 1-\sigma(t)\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s),&\text{if % }x_{s}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]\\ \delta_{x_{s}^{i}x_{t}^{i}},&x_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}].\\ \end{cases}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT euler , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_s ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 - italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t - italic_s ) , end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (D.13)

In practice, we also use cÎ¸â¢(ğ’™t)â¢[i,xsi]subscriptğ‘ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–c_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})[i,x_{s}^{i}]italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) [ italic_i , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] to approximate the true conditional distribution p0â¢(xsi|ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMp_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) when sampling from Eq.Â D.13.

D.4 Equivalence of Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping and Euler method under log-linear noise schedule

By comparing Eq.Â D.8 and Eq.Â D.13, we observe that both the Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping and Euler methods can be interpreted similarly:

  • â€¢

    If xtisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an unmasked token, keep it unchanged, i.e., xsi=xtisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–x_{s}^{i}=x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • â€¢

    If xtisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a masked token, first determine whether it will be unmasked with a probability Ïˆâ¢(t,s)ğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘ \psi(t,s)italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , italic_s ). If it is to be unmasked, then sample xsisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–x_{s}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from p0â¢(xsi|ğ’™tUM)subscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMp_{0}(x_{s}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}^{\textrm{UM}})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT UM end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

The only difference lies in the analytic form of Ïˆâ¢(t,s)ğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘ \psi(t,s)italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , italic_s ). For the two methods, according to Eqs.Â D.8 andÂ D.13, their corresponding Ïˆâ¢(t,s)ğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘ \psi(t,s)italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , italic_s ) are given as follows:

Ïˆtweedieâ¢(t,s)=eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(s)âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t),superscriptğœ“tweedieğ‘¡ğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘ superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡\displaystyle\psi^{\text{tweedie}}(t,s)=\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(s)}-e^{-\bar{% \sigma}(t)}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}},italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT tweedie end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_s ) = divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_s ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (D.14)
Ïˆeulerâ¢(t,s)=Ïƒâ¢(t)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)â¢(tâˆ’s).superscriptğœ“eulerğ‘¡ğ‘ ğœğ‘¡superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘ \displaystyle\psi^{\text{euler}}(t,s)=\sigma(t)\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}{1-e% ^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}}(t-s).italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT euler end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t , italic_s ) = italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t - italic_s ) . (D.15)

In general cases, these two expressions are not equivalent. However, if we choose a log-linear noise schedule ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)=1âˆ’logâ¡(1âˆ’(1âˆ’Ïµ)â¢t)Â¯ğœğ‘¡111italic-Ïµğ‘¡\bar{\sigma}(t)=1-\log\left(1-(1-\epsilon)t\right)overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) = 1 - roman_log ( 1 - ( 1 - italic_Ïµ ) italic_t ), both Eq.Â D.15 and Eq.Â D.14 can be simplified to the same form Ïˆâ¢(t,s)ğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘ \psi(t,s)italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , italic_s ) as follows:

Ïˆâ¢(t,s)=tâˆ’st,ğœ“ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ ğ‘¡\psi(t,s)=\frac{t-s}{t},italic_Ïˆ ( italic_t , italic_s ) = divide start_ARG italic_t - italic_s end_ARG start_ARG italic_t end_ARG , (D.16)

which shows that these two sampling methods are equivalent under a log-linear noise schedule.

D.5 Discuss on the expectation of NFEs

In this part, we show that given the noise schedule Ïƒâ¢(t)ğœğ‘¡\sigma(t)italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t ) and a set of time steps {t0=0,â‹¯,tn=T}formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¡00â‹¯subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘‡\{t_{0}=0,\cdots,t_{n}=T\}{ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , â‹¯ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T }, the NFEs can be treated as a random variable with a calculable expected value for both Euler method and Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method.

Let lğ‘™litalic_l denote the length of the generated sequence and Nkâˆˆ{0,â‹¯,l}subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0â‹¯ğ‘™N_{k}\in\{0,\cdots,l\}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , â‹¯ , italic_l } denote the number of dimensions that ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x changed in [tkâˆ’1,tk)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜[t_{k-1},t_{k})[ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Without loss of generality, we first consider the unconditional generation case where l=dğ‘™ğ‘‘l=ditalic_l = italic_d. The NFEs, E-NFEs, and Nksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜N_{k}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be expressed as

NFEsâ¢(n)=âˆ‘k=1nğ•€â¢(Nkâ‰ 0),NFEsğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ•€subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0\text{NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{I}(N_{k}\neq 0),NFEs ( italic_n ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 ) , (D.17)
E-NFEsâ¢(n)=âˆ‘k=1nğ”¼â¢[ğ•€â¢(Nkâ‰ 0)]=âˆ‘k=1nPâ¢(Nkâ‰ 0),E-NFEsğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ•€subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{I}(N_{k}\neq 0)]=\sum_{k=1}^% {n}P(N_{k}\neq 0),E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ blackboard_I ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 ) ] = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 ) , (D.18)
Nk=âˆ‘i=1dğ•€â¢(xtkâˆ’1iâ‰ [M],xtki=[M]).subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘ğ•€formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–delimited-[]MN_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\mathbb{I}(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[% \textbf{M}]).italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) . (D.19)

Furthermore, we note that the dğ‘‘ditalic_d dimensions are independent. According to Eqs.Â D.8 andÂ D.13, the probability ps|tâ‹…,iâ¢([M]|ğ’™t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…ğ‘–conditionaldelimited-[]Msubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) depends only on time and xtisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–x_{t}^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT while independent of the other dimensions of ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, ps|tâ‹…,iâ¢([M]|ğ’™t)=ps|tâ‹…,iâ¢([M]|xti)superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…ğ‘–conditionaldelimited-[]Msubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘ ğ‘¡â‹…ğ‘–conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|{\bm{x}}_{t})=p_{s|t}^{\cdot,i}([\textbf{M}]|x_% {t}^{i})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… , italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Therefore, whether a token changes from masked to unmasked is independent across the dğ‘‘ditalic_d dimensions333The independence applies to whether a token changes from masked to unmasked. However, the specific unmasked token a masked token changes to depends on other dimensions.:

pâ¢(ğ•€â¢(xs1=[M]),â‹¯,ğ•€â¢(xsd=[M])|ğ•€â¢(xt1=[M]),â‹¯,ğ•€â¢(xtd=[M]))ğ‘ğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ 1delimited-[]Mâ‹¯conditionalğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘‘delimited-[]Mğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1delimited-[]Mâ‹¯ğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘‘delimited-[]M\displaystyle p\left(\mathbb{I}(x_{s}^{1}=[\textbf{M}]),\cdots,\mathbb{I}(x_{s% }^{d}=[\textbf{M}])|\mathbb{I}(x_{t}^{1}=[\textbf{M}]),\cdots,\mathbb{I}(x_{t}% ^{d}=[\textbf{M}])\right)italic_p ( blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) , â‹¯ , blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) | blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) , â‹¯ , blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ) (D.20)
=\displaystyle== âˆi=1dpâ¢(ğ•€â¢(xsi=[M])|ğ•€â¢(xti=[M])).superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ ğ‘–delimited-[]Mğ•€superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M\displaystyle\prod_{i=1}^{d}p\left(\mathbb{I}(x_{s}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])|\mathbb{% I}(x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])\right).âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) | blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) ) . (D.21)

Since ğ’™Tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘‡{\bm{x}}_{T}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists entirely of masked tokens with probability one, each dimension of ğ•€â¢(xtkâˆ’1iâ‰ [M],xtki=[M])ğ•€formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–delimited-[]M\mathbb{I}(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])blackboard_I ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) is independent. Consequently, Nksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜N_{k}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a binomial distribution with parameters dğ‘‘ditalic_d and rksubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as Nkâˆ¼Binomialâ¢(d,rk)similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜Binomialğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜N_{k}\sim\text{Binomial}(d,r_{k})italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Binomial ( italic_d , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where rk=pâ¢(xtkâˆ’1iâ‰ [M],xtki=[M])subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–delimited-[]Mr_{k}=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) represents the probability that xisuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x^{i}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes within the interval [tkâˆ’1,tk)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜[t_{k-1},t_{k})[ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in each dimension. Therefore, we can further simplify Eq.Â D.18:

E-NFEsâ¢(n)=âˆ‘k=1nPâ¢(Nkâ‰ 0)=âˆ‘k=1n(1âˆ’(1âˆ’rk)d).E-NFEsğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›1superscript1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘‘\text{E-NFEs}(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}P(N_{k}\neq 0)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(1-(1-r_{k})^{d}).E-NFEs ( italic_n ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  0 ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - ( 1 - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (D.22)

By definition of rksubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and property of absorbing diffusion:

rksubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜\displaystyle r_{k}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =pâ¢(xtkâˆ’1iâ‰ [M],xtki=[M])absentğ‘formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–delimited-[]M\displaystyle=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])= italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) (D.23)
=pâ¢(xtkâˆ’1iâ‰ [M]|xtki=[M])â¢âˆj=k+1npâ¢(xtjâˆ’1i=[M]|xtji=[M])â¢pâ¢(xtni=[M])absentğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘–conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘—ğ‘˜1ğ‘›ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1ğ‘–conditionaldelimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ‘–delimited-[]Mğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘–delimited-[]M\displaystyle=p(x_{t_{k-1}}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{k}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])% \prod_{j=k+1}^{n}p(x_{t_{j-1}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}]|x_{t_{j}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])p(x% _{t_{n}}^{i}=[\textbf{M}])= italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] ) (D.24)

(D.25)

Eq.Â D.25 can be determined given the sampling method and noise schedule.

For the Euler method, based on Eq.Â D.13, we can derive that:

rk=(Ïƒâ¢(tk)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(tk)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(tk)â¢(tkâˆ’tkâˆ’1))â¢âˆj=k+1n(1âˆ’Ïƒâ¢(tj)â¢eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(tj)1âˆ’eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(tj)â¢(tjâˆ’tjâˆ’1)).subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘—ğ‘˜1ğ‘›1ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—1r_{k}=(\sigma(t_{k})\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k})}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{k})}% }(t_{k}-t_{k-1}))\prod_{j=k+1}^{n}(1-\sigma(t_{j})\frac{e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j}% )}}{1-e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t_{j})}}(t_{j}-t_{j-1})).italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Ïƒ ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) . Specifically, if we adopt a log-linear noise schedule and let tk=knsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ‘›t_{k}=\frac{k}{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG, according to SectionÂ D.4, the Euler method and Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method are equivalent. (D.31)

Appendix E Discussion for mean parameterization and RADD

Equivalence of modeling

Analogous to the x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT prediction in continuous state diffusion models, Austin etÂ al. [20] and Campbell etÂ al. [26] used the mean parameterization ğÎ¸â¢(ğ’™t,t)subscriptğğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t},t)bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ) to learn the the reverse density p0|tiâ¢(x0i|ğ’™t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditional0ğ‘¡ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p_{0|t}^{i}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 | italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), i=1â¢â‹¯â¢dğ‘–1â‹¯ğ‘‘i=1\cdots ditalic_i = 1 â‹¯ italic_d. According to the analytic form of reverse distribution in Eq.Â D.8, letting s=0ğ‘ 0s=0italic_s = 0, we have:

p0|tiâ¢(x0i|ğ’™t)={p0â¢(x0i|ğ’™tUM),x0iâ‰ [M],xti=[M],0,x0i=[M],xti=[M],Î´x0iâ¢xti,xtiâ‰ [M].superscriptsubscriptğ‘conditional0ğ‘¡ğ‘–conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡casessubscriptğ‘0conditionalsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡UMformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]M0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–delimited-[]Msuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Msubscriptğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]Mp_{0|t}^{i}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t})=\begin{cases}{p_{0}(x_{0}^{i}|{\bm{x}}_{t}% ^{\textrm{UM}})},&x_{0}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ 0,&x_{0}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],x_{t}^{i}=[\textbf{M}],\\ \delta_{x_{0}^{i}x_{t}^{i}},&x_{t}^{i}\neq[\textbf{M}].\end{cases}italic_p , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ M ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (E.1)

This shows that the mean prediction is equivalent to learning conditional distributions on clean data. In conjunction with our discussion in SectionÂ 3.1, the mean parameterization should be time-independent, denoted as ğÎ¸â¢(ğ’™t)subscriptğğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and is equivalent to our reparameterized ğ’„Î¸â¢(ğ’™t)subscriptğ’„ğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{c}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Empirical results He etÂ al. [25] and Sahoo etÂ al. [47], which demonstrate that the time-independent model ğÎ¸â¢(ğ’™t)subscriptğğœƒsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{\mu}}_{\theta}({\bm{x}}_{t})bold_italic_Î¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) performs well, also validate our theory.

Equivalence of training objectives

Shi etÂ al. [42] proved that the training loss for score parameterization (i.e., DSE loss) and mean parameterization (i.e., negative ELBO loss) is equivalent.

Equivalence of sampling methods

Comparing our SectionÂ D.2 with Shi etÂ al. [42], Sahoo etÂ al. [47], it is evident that the Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method for score parameterization is equivalent to the sampling method for mean prediction as follows:

qÎ¸â¢(xs|xt)=pâ¢(xs|xt,x0=Î¼â¢(xt))={Catâ¢(xs;xt),xtâ‰ [M],Catâ¢(xs;1âˆ’Î±s1âˆ’Î±tâ¢ğ[M]+Î±sâˆ’Î±t1âˆ’Î±tâ¢Î¼â¢(xt)),xt=[M].subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥0ğœ‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡casesCatsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡delimited-[]MCatsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ 1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ 1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğdelimited-[]Msubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğœ‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡delimited-[]Mq_{\theta}(x_{s}|x_{t})=p(x_{s}|x_{t},x_{0}=\mu(x_{t}))=\begin{cases}\textrm{% Cat}(x_{s};x_{t}),&x_{t}\neq[\textbf{M}],\\ \textrm{Cat}(x_{s};\frac{1-\alpha_{s}}{1-\alpha_{t}}\mathbf{e}_{[\textbf{M}]}+% \frac{\alpha_{s}-\alpha_{t}}{1-\alpha_{t}}\mu(x_{t})),&x_{t}=[\textbf{M}].\\ \end{cases}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î¼ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = { start_ROW start_CELL Cat ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  [ M ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL Cat ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; divide start_ARG 1 - italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ M ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_Î¼ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ M ] . end_CELL end_ROW (E.2)

Here, Î±tsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha_{t}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the probability of a token remaining unmasked at time tğ‘¡titalic_t, which equals eâˆ’ÏƒÂ¯â¢(t)superscriptğ‘’Â¯ğœğ‘¡e^{-\bar{\sigma}(t)}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for score parameterization. Therefore, Eq.Â E.2 and Eq.Â D.8 is equivalent.

Appendix F Algorithms for training and sampling

Appendix G Experimental details

G.1 Model details

We implemented our RADD model based on the SEDD architecture, an encoder-only transformer modelÂ [53, 54]. Our model incorporates rotary positional encodingÂ [55] but excludes all parts related to time conditioning (i.e., TimeEmbedding, adaLN-zero blockÂ [56]). Instead, we added a softmax operation at the end of the neural network to ensure the output is a valid conditional distribution. Our modification resulted in a reduction of 7 million parameters, leading to an 8% decrease from the original 90 million non-embedding parameters of the SEDD small model.

G.2 Training details

We trained our RADD-DSE model following the configuration settings from [29]. The training configuration is as follows:

  • â€¢

    Batch Size: 512

  • â€¢

    Learning Rate: 3Ã—10âˆ’43superscript1043\times 10^{-4}3 Ã— 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  • â€¢

    Exponential Moving Average (EMA):0.9999

  • â€¢

    Gradient Clipping: Gradient norm clipped to 1

  • â€¢

    Warmup Schedule: Applied for the first 2500 iterations

  • â€¢

    weight decay: 0

  • â€¢

    dropout rate: 0.1

For the models RADD-tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE, RADD-Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE, and RADD-AO, we referenced the hyperparameters from [42]. The modifications included setting the weight decay to 0.03 and the dropout rate to 0.02. Due to limited computational resources, we did not conduct a hyperparameter search and ran experiments directly with these configurations. Further hyperparameter tuning may improve performance.

We trained on nodes of 32 V100 32G GPUs with float16 precision.

G.3 Unconditional Generation Details

For unconditional generation, we employed a log-linear noise schedule. As illustrated in SectionÂ 3.2, the Euler method and the Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method are equivalent under this case. In practice, the implementation of the Euler method and the Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method remains the same for RADD but differs for SEDD. So we measure the perplexity of SEDD by Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping method which performs slightly better while it suffices to measure the perplexity of RADD once.

The following procedures were used for generating samples:

  • â€¢

    RADD Small: We generated 1024 samples to calculate the average value.

  • â€¢

    SEDD Small: We utilized the results provided for steps less than 2048 and performed our evaluation at 4096 steps.

No annealing methods (e.g., top-p or top-k sampling) were applied in our sampling process.

G.4 Further evaluation of generative perplexity

Runtime Comparison

To assess inference efficiency, we measured the inference time on a single NVIDIA 4090 GPU with a batch size of 8, averaged over 1024 samples. The results are summarized in TableÂ 3.

Across all sampling steps, the RADD model consistently required the shortest sampling time while maintaining similar perplexity levels to the SEDD model. Quantitatively, RADD achieved a speed-up of 2.5 to 3.5 times, as shown in TableÂ 3. These findings align with the analysis of the E-NFEs in Fig.Â 2, validating the effectiveness of the RADD model and the caching strategy. They also demonstrate the practical implications of our TheoremÂ 1.

Sampling as any-order autoregressive models

As outlined in TheoremÂ 1, ğ’„Î¸subscriptğ’„ğœƒ{\bm{c}}_{\theta}bold_italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be interpreted as a conditional distribution over clean data. One natural approach is to use this directly for generating samples, similar to any-order autoregressive models. However, there are d!ğ‘‘d!italic_d ! possible ways to decompose the joint distribution into conditional distributions. We tested three representative cases:

  • â€¢

    forward: pâ¢(x1â¢â‹¯â¢xd)=âˆk=1dpâ¢(xk|x(<k))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥absentğ‘˜p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{k}|x^{(<k)})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( < italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

  • â€¢

    backward: pâ¢(x1â¢â‹¯â¢xd)=âˆk=1dpâ¢(xk|x(>k))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘˜1ğ‘‘ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥absentğ‘˜p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{k}|x^{(>k)})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( > italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

  • â€¢

    random: Ï€âˆ¼UÏ€similar-toğœ‹subscriptğ‘ˆğœ‹\pi\sim U_{\pi}italic_Ï€ âˆ¼ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï€ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p(x1â‹¯xd)=âˆk=1dp(xÏ€â¢(k)|xÏ€(<k)p(x^{1}\cdots x^{d})=\prod_{k=1}^{d}p(x^{\pi(k)}|x^{\pi(<k)}italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ï€ ( < italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT)

The results are presented in TableÂ 4. Perplexity was calculated as the average over 1024 samples. For the random case, we calculated the average perplexity across different randomly generated Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€. Generally, we found that directly sampling from the conditional distribution resulted in higher perplexity compared to Tweedie Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„-leaping or the Euler method with similar computational costs. Among the different decomposition orders, the forward order demonstrated the best performance.

Appendix H Additional experimental results

H.1 Additional samples

Additional unconditionally and conditionally generated text of RADD-tâ¢-DCEğ‘¡-DCEt\textrm{-DCE}italic_t -DCE and RADD-Î»â¢-DCEğœ†-DCE\lambda\textrm{-DCE}italic_Î» -DCE are reported in Figs. 3 to 6. All samples are generated with 1024 steps under a log-linear noise schedule.
